item.description:
ðŸ™ Ð¡Ð¿Ð°ÑÐ¸Ð±Ð¾ LeetCode Ð·Ð° Ð·Ð°Ð¼ÐµÑ‡Ð°Ñ‚ÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ½ÑƒÑŽ Ð·Ð°Ð´Ð°Ñ‡Ñƒ “807. Max Increase to Keep City Skyline”

Ð¡Ð¾Ð´ÐµÑ€Ð¶Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ
  • Ð—Ð°Ð´Ð°Ñ‡Ð°
    • ÐžÐ³Ñ€Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ

Ð—Ð°Ð´Ð°Ñ‡Ð°

Ð˜Ð¼ÐµÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´, ÑÐ¾ÑÑ‚Ð¾ÑÑ‰Ð¸Ð¹ Ð¸Ð· $n \times n$ Ð±Ð»Ð¾ÐºÐ¾Ð², Ð³Ð´Ðµ ÐºÐ°Ð¶Ð´Ñ‹Ð¹ Ð±Ð»Ð¾Ðº ÑÐ¾Ð´ÐµÑ€Ð¶Ð¸Ñ‚ Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð½Ð¾ Ð¾Ð´Ð½Ð¾ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ Ð² Ñ„Ð¾Ñ€Ð¼Ðµ Ð²ÐµÑ€Ñ‚Ð¸ÐºÐ°Ð»ÑŒÐ½Ð¾Ð¹ ÐºÐ²Ð°Ð´Ñ€Ð°Ñ‚Ð½Ð¾Ð¹ Ð¿Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¼Ñ‹. Ð”Ð°Ð½Ð° Ð·Ð°Ð¸Ð½Ð´ÐµÐºÑÐ¸Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð½Ð°Ñ Ñ 0 Ð¼Ð°Ñ‚Ñ€Ð¸Ñ†Ð° Ñ†ÐµÐ»Ñ‹Ñ… Ñ‡Ð¸ÑÐµÐ» grid, Ð³Ð´Ðµ grid[i][j] - Ð¿Ñ€ÐµÐ´ÑÑ‚Ð°Ð²Ð»ÑÐµÑ‚ ÑÐ¾Ð±Ð¾Ð¹ Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾Ñ‚Ñƒ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ, Ð½Ð°Ñ…Ð¾Ð´ÑÑ‰ÐµÐ³Ð¾ÑÑ Ð² Ð±Ð»Ð¾ÐºÐµ Ð½Ð° i-Ð¾Ð¹ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ð¾ÐºÐµ Ð² j-Ð¾Ð¼ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð»Ð±Ñ†Ðµ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð°.

Ð“Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° - ÑÑ‚Ð¾ Ð²Ð½ÐµÑˆÐ½Ð¸Ð¹ ÐºÐ¾Ð½Ñ‚ÑƒÑ€ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð°, Ð¾Ð±Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ð½Ð½Ñ‹Ð¹ Ð²ÑÐµÐ¼Ð¸ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸ÑÐ¼Ð¸, ÐµÑÐ´Ð¸ ÑÐ¼Ð¾Ñ‚Ñ€ÐµÑ‚ÑŒ Ð½Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´ Ð¸Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð»ÐµÐºÐ°. Ð“Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ñ ÐºÐ°Ð¶Ð´Ð¾Ð¹ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð½Ñ‹ ÑÐ²ÐµÑ‚Ð° Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð²Ñ‹Ð³Ð»ÑÐ´ÐµÑ‚ÑŒ Ð¿Ð¾-Ñ€Ð°Ð·Ð½Ð¾Ð¼Ñƒ.

Ð Ð°Ð·Ñ€ÐµÑˆÐ°ÐµÑ‚ÑÑ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ð²Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾Ñ‚Ñƒ Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ Ð½Ð° Ð»ÑŽÐ±ÑƒÑŽ Ð²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ð½Ñƒ, Ð½Ð¾ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð½Ðµ Ð´Ð¾Ð»Ð¶ÐµÐ½ Ð¼ÐµÐ½ÑÑ‚ÑŒÑÑ Ñ Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¾Ð¹ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð½Ñ‹ ÑÐ²ÐµÑ‚Ð°.

ÐžÑ‚ Ð²Ð°Ñ Ñ‚Ñ€ÐµÐ±ÑƒÐµÑ‚ÑÑ Ð²Ñ‹Ñ‡Ð¸ÑÐ»Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð¼Ð°ÐºÑÐ¸Ð¼Ð°Ð»ÑŒÐ½ÑƒÑŽ ÑÑƒÐ¼Ð¼Ñƒ, Ð½Ð° ÐºÐ¾Ñ‚Ð¾Ñ€ÑƒÑŽ Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶ÐµÑ‚ Ð±Ñ‹Ñ‚ÑŒ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡ÐµÐ½Ð° Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾Ñ‚Ð° Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¹ Ð±ÐµÐ· Ð¸Ð·Ð¼ÐµÐ½ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ñ Ð»ÑŽÐ±Ð¾Ð¹ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð½Ñ‹ ÑÐ²ÐµÑ‚Ð°.

ÐžÐ³Ñ€Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ñ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ

  • n == grid.length
  • $\forall i \in \{0, \dots, n - 1\}: $ n == grid[i].length
  • $2 \leq n \leq 50$
  • $0 \leq grid[i][j] \leq 100$

ÐŸÑ€Ð¸Ð¼ÐµÑ€Ñ‹

Input: grid = [ [3, 0, 8, 4],
[2, 4, 5, 7],
[9, 2, 6, 3],
[0, 3, 1, 0] ]
Output: 35
`grid` Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð¿Ð¾ÑÐ»Ðµ Ð¼Ð°ÐºÑÐ¸Ð¼Ð°Ð»ÑŒÐ½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ Ð²Ð¾Ð·Ð¼Ð¾Ð¶Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾Ñ‚ Ð²ÑÐµÑ… Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¹
new_grid = [ [8, 4, 8, 7],
[7, 4, 7, 7],
[9, 4, 8, 7],
[3, 3, 3, 3] ]

Input: grid = [[0,0,0],[0,0,0],[0,0,0]]
Output: 0
ÐÐµÐ»ÑŒÐ·Ñ ÑƒÐ²ÐµÐ»Ð¸Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ÑŒ Ð½Ð¸ Ð¾Ð´Ð½Ð¾ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ, Ñ‚Ð°Ðº ÐºÐ°Ðº Ñ‚Ð¾Ð³Ð´Ð° Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð¸Ð·Ð¼ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ‚ÑÑ.

Ð ÐµÑˆÐµÐ½Ð¸Ðµ

  • ÐŸÑƒÑÑ‚ÑŒ Ð½Ð¾Ð²Ñ‹Ðµ Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾Ñ‚Ñ‹ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ð¹ ÑÑ‚Ð¾ $grid'$
  • Ð¢Ð°Ðº ÐºÐ°Ðº Ð¼Ñ‹ Ñ…Ð¾Ñ‚Ð¸Ð¼ Ð¼Ð°ÐºÑÐ¸Ð¼Ð¸Ð·Ð¸Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ $\underset{i, j}{\sum}\{grid'[i][j] - grid[i][j]\}$, Ñ‚Ð¾ Ð½Ð°Ð¼ Ð½ÐµÐ¾Ð±Ñ…Ð¾Ð´Ð¸Ð¼Ð¾ Ð¼Ð°ÐºÑÐ¸Ð¼Ð¸Ð·Ð¸Ñ€Ð¾Ð²Ð°Ñ‚ÑŒ $grid'[i][j]$ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ð²ÑÐµÑ… $i, j$
  • Ð—Ð°Ð¼ÐµÑ‚Ð¸Ð¼, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾
    • $\forall i, j: grid'[i][j] \leq \underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[i][k]\}$
    • $\forall i, j: grid'[i][j] \leq \underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[k][j]\}$
    • Ñ‚Ð°Ðº ÐºÐ°Ðº ÐµÑÐ»Ð¸ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ ÑÑ‚Ð°Ð½ÐµÑ‚ Ð²Ñ‹ÑˆÐµ, Ñ‡ÐµÐ¼ ÑÐ°Ð¼Ð¾Ðµ Ð²Ñ‹ÑÐ¾ÐºÐ¾Ðµ Ð·Ð´Ð°Ð½Ð¸Ðµ Ð² ÐµÐ³Ð¾ ÑÑ‚Ñ€Ð¾ÐºÐµ Ð¸Ð»Ð¸ ÑÑ‚Ð¾Ð»Ð±Ñ†Ðµ, Ñ‚Ð¾ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¸Ð·Ð¾Ð½Ñ‚ Ð³Ð¾Ñ€Ð¾Ð´Ð° Ð¸Ð·Ð¼ÐµÐ½Ð¸Ñ‚ÑÑ
  • Ð—Ð½Ð°Ñ‡Ð¸Ñ‚ $$\forall i, j: grid'[i][j] \leq \min(\underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[i][k]\}, \underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[k][j]\})$$
  • ÐžÑ‚ÑÑŽÐ´Ð° ÑƒÐ¶Ðµ Ð¾Ñ‡ÐµÐ²Ð¸Ð´Ð½Ð¾, Ñ‡Ñ‚Ð¾ $$grid'[i][j] = \min(\underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[i][k]\}, \underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[k][j]\})$$
  • Ð Ð¾Ñ‚Ð²ÐµÑ‚ ÑÑ‚Ð¾ $$\underset{i, j}{\sum}\{\min(\underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[i][k]\}, \underset{0 \leq k < n}{\max}\{grid[k][j]\}) - grid[i][j]\}$$
Python 

class Solution:
def maxIncreaseKeepingSkyline(self, grid: List[List[int]]) -> int:
row_max = list(map(max, grid))
col_max = list(map(max, zip(*grid)))
return sum(
min(row_max[i], col_max[j]) - val
for i, row in enumerate(grid)
for j, val in enumerate(row)
)

C++ 

#include <bits/stdc++.h>
#define len(a) (int)a.size()
using namespace std;
typedef string str;
class Solution {
public:
int maxIncreaseKeepingSkyline(vector<vector<int>>& grid) {
int n = len(grid);
vector<int> row_max(n, -1);
vector<int> col_max(n, -1);
for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
for (int j = 0; j < n; ++j) {
row_max[i] = max(row_max[i], grid[i][j]);
col_max[j] = max(col_max[j], grid[i][j]);
}
}
int res = 0;
for (int i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
for (int j = 0; j < n; ++j) {
res += min(row_max[i], col_max[j]) - grid[i][j];
}
}
return res;
}
};

JavaScript 

/**
* @param {number[][]} grid
* @return {number}
*/
var maxIncreaseKeepingSkyline = function(grid) {
const n = grid.length;
const row_max = Array(n).fill(-1);
const col_max = Array(n).fill(-1);
for (let i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
for (let j = 0; j < n; ++j) {
row_max[i] = Math.max(row_max[i], grid[i][j]);
col_max[j] = Math.max(col_max[j], grid[i][j]);
}
}
let res = 0;
for (let i = 0; i < n; ++i) {
for (let j = 0; j < n; ++j) {
res += Math.min(row_max[i], col_max[j]) - grid[i][j];
}
}
return res;
};

Python 

class Codec:
def encode(self, longUrl: str) -> str:
"""Encodes a URL to a shortened URL.
"""

def decode(self, shortUrl: str) -> str:
"""Decodes a shortened URL to its original URL.
"""
return shortUrl

class Solution {

}

item.title: How to Install Hugo Extended on Ubuntu 20.04
item.description:
All you need to install Hugo Extended is to download the corresponding .deb file from the hugo repository (can be found here ðŸ‘‰ link).

For now (September 2021), the corresponding release is hugo_extended_0.88.1_Linux-64bit.deb:

wget https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo/releases/download/v0.88.1/hugo_extended_0.88.1_Linux-64bit.deb

After that, it is enough to install this package using dpkg:

dpkg --install hugo_extended_0.88.1_Linux-64bit.deb

That’s all âœŒ

item.title: GSoC 2021 Final
item.description:
ðŸš€ Project

The goal of this project is to create Jupyter notebooks that will become detailed and intuitive tutorials containing the ideas behind, explanations and experimental analysis of the algorithms implemented in NetworkX. I decided to start with a tutorial on directed acyclic graphs (DAGs for short).

Under the project, I wrote a tutorial explaining the various concepts of graphs. The main ones were Directed Graph and Directed Acyclic Graph. In addition to explanation of the theory, I developed examples using NetworkX and found various real-world applications of these concepts.

Moreover, I wrote about topological sort - one of the most basic algorithms for working with DAGs. It was very interesting to describe step-by-step how this algorithm works in a clear and comprehensible manner.

You can read about it in details here.

âœ… Results

The main result of my work is the topological sort tutorial.

  • âœ… Corresponding merged PR: [GSoC contribution] Topological sort notebook.

Furthermore, during the work on DAGs module of NetworkX, I opened several PRs with improvements:

  • âœ… Merged PR to improve code base: [GSoC contribution] Improving functions descendants and ancestors in dag.py
  • âœ… Merged PR to improve documentation: [GSoC contribution] Adding examples to docstrings in dag.py

ðŸ¥³ Conclusion

I want to express my deep gratitude to my mentors: Eric Ma and Ross Barnowski. It was a real pleasure to work with you guys. I look forward to further productive cooperation.

item.title: GSoC 2021 Start
item.description:
ðŸŒž ï¸Summer 2021

I am happy to have been accepted to Google Summer of Code 2021 with the project “Pedagogical Interactive Notebooks for Algorithms Implemented in NetworkX". I will be writing code under the mentorship of Eric Ma and Ross Barnowski. The goal of this project is to create Jupyter notebooks that will become detailed and intuitive tutorials containing the ideas behind, explanations and experimental analysis of the algorithms implemented in NetworkX.

Let me tell you about how I got there.

ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ’» Google Summer of Code

The Google Summer of Code, often abbreviated to GSoC, is an international annual program in which Google awards stipends to students who successfully complete a 10-week free and open-source software coding project during their break from school. The program is open to university students aged 18 or over. The amount of the stipend depends on the purchasing power parity of the country where the student’s university is located. Project ideas are listed by host organizations involved in open-source software development, though students can also propose their own project ideas.

This year it has been essential to me not to miss the GSoC, so I have written down the estimated dates for the stages that are important for a student.

â° Timeline

  • âœ… Organizations Announced

    ðŸ“… early March

    ðŸ“ Students can begin discussing project ideas with open source organizations that accepted to participate as a mentor organization.

  • âœ… Student Application Period

    ðŸ“… end of March â€” mid-April

    ðŸ“ Students can register and submit their proposals to mentor organizations.

  • âœ… Application Review Period

    ðŸ“… mid-April â€” mid-May

    ðŸ“ Mentor organizations review and select student proposals.

  • âœ… Student Projects Announced

    ðŸ“… at the end of the review period

    ðŸ“ Accepted students are paired with a mentor and start planning their projects and milestones.

The key stage is the Student Application Period. That is when you have to figure out which project you want to work on and make a proposal for what you are going to do for it during the summer.

For those lucky ones, who were accepted, there are a few more important stages.

  • âœ… Community Bonding

    ðŸ“… from the moment student projects announced â€” early June

    ðŸ“ Students spend a month learning more about their organization’s community.

  • âœ… Coding, part 1

    ðŸ“… early June â€” mid-July

    ðŸ“ Students work on their Google Summer of Code projects.

  • âœ… First Evaluations

    ðŸ“… mid-July

    ðŸ“ Mentors and students submit their evaluations of one another.

  • âœ… Coding, part 2

    ðŸ“… mid-July â€” mid-August

    ðŸ“ Students work on their Google Summer of Code projects.

  • âœ… Final Evaluations

    ðŸ“… mid-August

    ðŸ“ Students submit their code, project summaries, and final evaluations of their mentors.

  • âœ… Results Announced

    ðŸ“… end of August

    ðŸ“ Students are notified of the pass/fail status of their Google Summer of Code projects.

ðŸ˜Ž My advice

The participation process for accepted students can vary from organization to organization. And here I have no recommendations for you.

By contrast, I have some advice to help you maximize your chance of being accepted into the GSoC.

ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ« Start as early as possible

Contact mentors early! The earlier you contact mentors, the earlier you may receive feedback from them to improve your proposal and the higher your chance of being accepted will be.

The answers of the mentors will make it clear whether it would be comfortable to work with them in the summer. It gives you more time to find the right mentor organization.

ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ« Focus on quality

Think about your choice of a project carefully, you are going to be doing it for a couple of months, so it is very important that you choose something you are going to enjoy.

Make sure you have thought about the project and understood its achievable goals. Your application should convince mentors that you are capable of completing the project. If you are not sure about anything, get in touch with mentors, they are ready to advise you.

The proposal template and examples of accepted proposals from previous years would be very useful to you. In my case, I used this proposal template and examples.

Remember that after you have been accepted, you can edit your proposal at any time.

ðŸ‘¨â€ðŸ« Show your technical skills

Create at least one Pull Request before the Student Application Period ends! The best way to do this is to close an issue from the project. Many projects have issues marked Good First Issue and closing such type of issue would be a good starting point.

Commit early and commit often! So that mentors can see and review your work.

âœŒ That is all I wanted to tell you today. I hope this post will be useful to you. Good luck and have a nice day!
